title: The best recipes for using up seasonal produce
summary: The best way to make sure you get the most of it is to plan your meals for the week and go with root vegetables. Root vegetables contain lots of vitamins and minerals, but donâ€™t have as much fiber as leafy greens do. You can use root vegetables in soups, stews, and even desserts. Preserve the fresh produce you have now and use it to preserve it in winter. Use leftovers to mix up your leftovers by incorporating seasonal produce with seasonal produce.

content.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...a}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...a,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("h2",null,"Plan your meals for the week."),mdx("p",null,"Before you start browsing recipes to make sure you use up all your veggies, take a few minutes to make a plan for what you\u2019ll cook this week. Do you want to try out a new recipe every day or is there a dish you\u2019d like to master? Maybe you want to use up your leftovers \u2014 those are always great opportunities to incorporate seasonal produce!"),mdx("h2",null,"Go with root vegetables."),mdx("p",null,"Root vegetables are great in winter, but they can be enjoyed all year round. You can use them in soups, stews, and even desserts! Some good options are carrots, beets, celeriac, fennel, parsnips, potatoes, radishes, rutabaga, and turnips. Potatoes are especially versatile; you can boil, mash, roast, or French fry them."),mdx("p",null,"Root vegetables contain lots of vitamins and minerals, but don\u2019t have as much fiber as leafy greens do. They can also be pretty high in carbs, so keep that in mind if you\u2019re watching your diet."),mdx("h2",null,"Cook up a big batch of grains & beans."),mdx("p",null,`This is a great option if you\u2019re not a big fan of root vegetables; after all, they don\u2019t really taste like anything other than, well, root vegetables! You can try out different recipes and pairings with grains, beans, and legumes.
What\u2019s great about grains and beans is that they\u2019re very cheap, can be bought in bulk, and make a ton of food. They\u2019re also a good source of fiber, protein, and vitamins and minerals.`),mdx("h2",null,"Use up canned goods."),mdx("p",null,`Canned goods are very useful in the wintertime, because you can make stews, soups, and casseroles with them. They also usually come in BPA-free cans, so even though they\u2019re not as healthy or good for the environment as fresh produce, they\u2019re definitely better than nothing.
Canned tomatoes, beans, and corn, for example, are good staples to have on hand. If you don\u2019t have any canned goods in your pantry, you can also make a meal out of canned vegetables \u2014 like beans, corn, and tomatoes.`),mdx("h2",null,"Preserve the fresh produce you have now."),mdx("p",null,"You can save a few veggies by preserving them. For example, you can freeze broccoli, cabbage, carrots, and cauliflower, you can pickle cucumbers and peppers, and you can turn apples, pears, and tomatoes into jam. You can also make your own kimchi, pickles, or fermented vegetables."),mdx("p",null,"If you live in a warm climate, you can make your own water-simmered citric fruits like oranges, lemons, or limes. You can also make your own jam, sauce, and chutney, which you can use in winter when your fresh produce is limited."),mdx("h2",null,"Get creative with leftovers!"),mdx("p",null,"Leftovers are awesome, but they can also get boring. Make sure to keep them exciting by putting a creative twist on them. You can try out different recipes and then portion them out to have them for several days in a row."),mdx("p",null,"You can also make sure to mix up your leftovers by incorporating seasonal produce. For example, you can make a quesadilla with tortillas, nacho cheese, and some cooked veggies \u2014 or make a stir-fry with seasonal produce, rice, and leftover meat. You can also make lasagna with seasonal produce and pasta or pizza slices with seasonal produce and bread."),mdx("h2",null,"What to do with all that cabbage?"),mdx("p",null,`Cabbage is a quintessential seasonal food \u2014 but what to do with it when there\u2019s too much of it? You can make kimchi with it, you can make sauerkraut with it, and you can make coleslaw with it.
Cabbage can also be used in soups, stews, and casseroles, or you can fry or roast it. You can use it to make a creamed dish, a pie, or a quiche. You can also use it to make quick and easy desserts \u2014 like cabbage pancakes, cabbage cookies, or cabbage cake.`),mdx("h2",null,"Summary"),mdx("p",null,"As you can see, there are lots of ways to take advantage of seasonal produce. The best way to make sure you get the most out of it is to plan your meals for the week and go with root vegetables. You can use grains and beans to bulk up meals, and you can preserve the fresh produce that\u2019s in season right now. Finally, you can get creative with leftovers, and you can use up all that cabbage!"))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...n}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...n,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Millennials and Gen Zers have been driving the demand for plant-based foods. More consumers today are adopting a lifestyle that focuses on balanced and healthy diets instead of restrictive fad diets.
In response to these changing preferences, businesses everywhere have started offering more vegetarian options. In fact, even fast food chains like McDonald\u2019s and Burger King have started adding meatless items to their menus in an effort to cater to this growing market segment. And with good reason. Millennials alone account for nearly one-third of the workforce \u2014 a massive presence that will only continue to grow in coming years.
This rise in popularity of meatless Mondays is not surprising given how many people now choose to eat less meat, fish, or any animal products on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Thursdays, Fridays or Saturdays.
If you\u2019re looking for ways to reduce your red meat intake without sacrificing taste or variety in your diet, consider instituting Meatless Mondays at your place of business as well as at home.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: When You're Short on Time: 30 Minute Meals or Less

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`In an ideal world, you would be able to dedicate hours of your day to cooking and preparing wholesome meals. However, with busy work schedules and other obligations, it can be challenging to find the time to cook a healthy meal every night. To help you out in your time of need, we\u2019ve compiled a list of quick and easy meals that take 30 minutes or less to make. These 30 minute meals or less will have you back on track in no time!
If you don\u2019t have much time to spend in the kitchen after work or school, but want to eat healthy without picking up fast food, we\u2019ve got your back. These quick and easy meals take 30 minutes or less from prep to finish. Each one is also perfect for busy weeknights when you don\u2019t have much time for elaborate dinners or lengthy prep sessions. From sheet pan suppers to skillet dinners and more, there are plenty of affordable and accessible ideas here so you can get a home-cooked meal on the table lickety-split\u2026`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: Need Some Recipe Inspiration? Try These

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Time to fire up that stove again, because this time it\u2019s for cooking! The Great British Bake Off is back with a brand new batch of amateur bakers ready to tackle tricky challenges. Instead of the usual judges, this time we have Prue, Noel and Sandi testing their skills in the kitchen.
For those who aren\u2019t familiar with the show, The Great British Bake Off is a contest where amateur bakers are tested on their baking skills. Contestants are asked to make pastry-based dishes that often feature unusual or difficult techniques, and are judged on appearance, taste and originality. In each episode they face two different challenges: a Signature Bake where they must create something using a specific ingredient or theme as inspiration; and a Technical Challenge which might see them making croquembouche or another difficult dish.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: Comfort Food Recipes to Warm Your Soul

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`It\u2019s the perfect time of year to cozy up with a blanket and dive into a bowl of steaming hot soup, casserole, or other home-style comfort food. Who can resist the wholesome aroma of a slow-cooked dish? Not us!
These dishes are filled with rich and savory ingredients that warm you from the inside out. They\u2019re also easy to make in large batches, which means you can enjoy them for dinner for several nights in a row without getting bored. And because these comforting meals are easy to double or triple, they\u2019re also excellent ideas for homesick college students or anyone who misses mom\u2019s home cooking. So, don your stretchy pants and get ready to dive into these 15 yummy comfort food recipes this season has to offer\u2026`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 5 Ways to Cook with Tofu - For Meat-Eaters and Vegetarians
6 Ways to Make Your Diet More Nutritious

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:t,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:t,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"Do you feel like your diet just isn\u2019t cutting it? Maybe it\u2019s time to amp things up a notch. A good diet is essential to a healthy life, and with so many different diets being promoted these days, it can be hard to separate fact from fiction. When it comes to nutrition, there are so many factors to take into account. You might know that vitamins and minerals are important and that fats, proteins, and carbs all play an important role in your diet. But how do you actually make sure that your diet reflects those principles? Here are some tips and tricks on how you can make your diet more nutritious:"))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: Nutrient Dense Superfoods That Improve Overall Health

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Superfoods are nutrient-dense foods that have a high concentration of disease-fighting vitamins and minerals. They also tend to be high in antioxidants, fiber, and other phytonutrients that help protect your body from free radicals and diseases. These healthy, natural foods can be found in almost any corner of the globe. Many indigenous cultures eat these as staples because of their abundant benefits for the human body.
Superfoods generally have impressive quantities of some or many nutrients, such as carotenoids (vitamin A), flavonoids, vitamins C and E, or omega-3 fatty acids (ALA). There are many types of superfoods; here is a list of 20 worth adding to your diet:`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 5 Simple Tips for Eating Healthier Every Day

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`You see it everywhere these days: people talking about eating healthier, cleaner and more nutritious foods. Even famous athletes are getting in on the action. Superstars like LeBron James and Tom Brady are known for their high performance on game day as much as their off-season diet. The only problem with all of these healthy eating fads is that they can feel like a big challenge to follow every single day. But what if you could make it easier?
It\u2019t not crazy to think you can eat healthier every day. After all, you aren\u2019t permanently locked into an unhealthy lifestyle. Your habits change over time, which means your diet can too! You just need a plan to get there, which is why we\u2019ve outlined five simple tips that will help you eat healthier every day without feeling like a chore.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 3 Steps to Spring Clean Your Eating Habits

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Thinking about that New Year\u2019s resolution to eat healthier again? We see it every year, thousands of people vowing to eat clean and fit in exercise after a holiday season filled with excess. But what does that even mean anymore? Eating healthy is no longer as straightforward as it once was. There are so many different diets, food trends, and nutrition philosophies floating around out there today, how are you supposed to know what will work for you long-term and not just for one fleeting moment?
If the past several years have shown us anything, it\u2019s that eating clean is here to stay. So instead of feeling like you\u2019re trying on another new fad diet or eating trend, let this be your guidepost back to the basics of eating wholesome food that helps your body in the long run. Clean eating is not about perfection or cutting out entire food groups at all; it\u2019s about making more informed choices about the things you put into your body on a daily basis. Read further to learn more\u2026`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 10 Ways to Use up Leftover Cooked Rice

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"When you\u2019ve cooked a batch of rice and there\u2019s just a little bit left, it can be disappointing. You might find yourself thinking there is no way to use that up and it will end up going bad before you find another use for it. However, this isn\u2019t the case. There are lots of ways to use up leftover cooked rice that are both delicious and won\u2019t see it go to waste. In fact, you might find yourself looking forward to cooking up a second batch so you can have some leftovers again! Luckily, these ideas will help you make the most of your leftover rice."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
